Paper provides a comprehensive study of Ni-Cu catalysts on alumina, focusing on the effects of metal loading, reduction temperatures, and bimetallic interactions on catalyst properties and adsorption behaviour of model organic molecules. Introduction of metal reduces catalyst surface area. Low Cu loadings promote formation of isolated Cu sites, higher result in large CuO clusters. Ni catalysts have composition consisting of a mixture of NiO, NiO-like, and spinel species and the surface is primarily covered by NiO. Bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts reveal Cu enhanced hydrogenation ability and reducibility. Acidity, primarily originating from alumina, decreases with increasing metal loading, however increasing nickel loading induces new type of sites capable of decomposing NH₃. Reduced acidity limits anisole and guaiacol adsorption, while the presence of Cu provides additional adsorption sites for furfuryl alcohol. Organics exhibit distinct adsorption modes with following desorption and/or decomposition during thermal heating influenced by metal loading, catalyst composition and organics type. Incorporating Ni and Cu affects coke deposits: the most deposits are formed on alumina after guaiacol adsorption, while anisole leaves no carbonaceous residues. The study highlights the importance of reduction conditions on catalytic performance, advocating further research on adsorption under reaction-like conditions to understand the catalysts’ behaviour in practical applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-Cu catalysts Organics adsorption Anisole Guaiacol Furfuryl alcohol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ni-Cu/Al₂O₃ catalysts are widely used in the valorisation of phenolics due to their high activity, stability, and selectivity in hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions [1–4]. These catalysts facilitate the conversion of phenolics derived from lignocellulosic biomass into valuable chemicals, such as guaiacol to toluene and xylene [5] or eugenol/propyl phenol to phenol and cresol [6,7], and biofuels. Phenolics may undergo several reactions such as hydrogenation, demethylation, and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), each of which typically requires different active sites. Therefore, while the activity in the HDO of phenolics depends on reaction temperature and pressure [8], the crucial parameters also include the state of the surface and the nature of the active sites. Nickel provides active sites for hydrogenation, enhancing the saturation of aromatic rings and the removal of oxygen-containing functional groups, while Al₂O₃ as the support ensures a large surface area, good dispersion of nickel particles, and resistance to sintering, which together improve the overall catalytic performance [9–11]. The synergistic effect between Ni and Al₂O₃ enables efficient upgrading of phenolics into hydrocarbons, contributing to the development of sustainable and renewable energy resources. The surface of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts typically contains metal (Ni) particles of various sizes, oxidation states, and phase structures, directly influencing the adsorption of phenolics and reaction course. The works of Yan et al. [12] and Novodarszki et al. [13], explored the role of the acidic sites and metal sites on guaiacol HDO reactions over supported Ni catalysts. They attributed the reactions to acid and metal sites. However, they did not investigate the effect of adsorption over the different catalytic sites and the surface morphology. To facilitate CO bond cleavage via hydrogenolysis, the presence of acid sites is essential [8]. These acid sites typically originate from the support material, such as Al2O3. Specifically, the surface -OH groups can adsorb the hydroxyl or methoxy groups of phenolics, thereby enhancing HDO capability [14]. Additionally, these acid sites can dehydrate phenolics by proton donation to the aromatic ring, further supporting the hydrogenolysis process [15]. In addition to acid sites, the presence of metal particles plays a crucial role as well. The interaction between metal particles and acid sites facilitates the anisole HDO [16]. Conversely, a higher abundance of difficult-to-reduce Ni particles can suppress the synergistic effect between Ni and acid sites [8]. Ni has the ability to form alloys for instance with Cu or Fe [17,18], altering the structure and activity of the Ni active sites. This results in increased adsorption strength of cyclohexanol formed from phenol, where Fe sites adsorb the hydroxyl group while Ni activates hydrogen [18]. Conversely, alloying Ni with Ga affects negatively the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring [19]. Phenolics interact via H-bonding or are adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites of alumina [20]. There are different adsorption modes depending on the reaction temperature. Cu/Al₂O₃ catalysts have also been investigated for the hydrodeoxygenation reactions [21,22], although results indicate that monometallic Cu catalysts exhibit limited activity in HDO reactions compared to catalysts containing Ni. For instance, a study evaluating various catalysts for phenol HDO found that Cu catalysts had lower activity and selectivity towards deoxygenated products [22]. However, when combining Cu with Ni, the performance of Ni catalysts in hydrogenation and HDO reactions of lignin-derived phenolic compounds can be significantly enhanced. This is often ascribed to enhanced Ni reducibility and dispersion [23] due to Cu addition. Cu can also promote selective hydrodeoxygenation pathways, which is crucial for preserving desired hydrocarbon structures [24]. The effect is explained by interactions between Ni and Cu leading to the formation of bimetallic sites with unique electronic properties [24,25]. Consequently, the Ni/Cu ratio [17,24] plays a critical role in tuning the performance of bimetallic catalysts. On the other hand, opposite findings presenting no or negative Cu effect were also published [26,27], however significantly less than those showing a positive effect. For example, Garcia-Sanchez [27] claims that these synergetic effects are valid for hydrogenation reactions, but not for HDO. He showed that Ni catalyst was the most active in guaiacol HDO because the addition of Cu resulted in the formation of large Cu-rich alloys, that were less active. In spite of the fact that Ni-Cu catalysts are generally considered as catalysts active in hydrodeoxygenation reactions, in the scientific literature there is only a limited number of reports on the adsorption of oxygenates on Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalysts that is essential for the overall activity and selectivity. Moreover, there is a diversity in active sites arising from changes in the catalysts composition, morphology and structure, which control the type of adsorption sites and the interactions of adsorbed species [28]. The variety of the sites in a catalyst may lead to the formation of different co-adsorbed species, which might be exploited in hydrogenation/deoxygenation reactions. Therefore, our aim was to describe and understand the adsorption/desorption behaviour of model organic compounds (anisole, guaiacol and furfuryl alcohol) on alumina-supported Ni-Cu catalysts, and to determine their adsorption capacity. This necessitates comprehensive characterization of catalysts focused in particular on adsorption studies and the influence of catalyst pre-treatment conditions. We have demonstrated that the adsorption of phenolics and furanics is influenced by reactant type and the catalyst's physico-chemical properties. Such analyses are critical in developing catalysts for biomass conversion, where the desorption properties affect the overall catalytic performance in reactions like HDO. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts In this work, five sets of samples were designed. The first one included four Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with different metal loading (wt. %) as denoted in their names Ni6, Ni10, Ni14, and Ni16. The second set included five Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with different metal loading (wt. %) as denoted in their names Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, Cu5, and Cu10. The third set contained catalysts with various Ni:Cu molar ratios (9.5-to-0.5, 9-to-1, 2-to-1, 1-to-1, 1-to-2) with the same total metal molar loading equal to the Ni loading of 10 wt. %. Samples are denoted as Ni9.5Cu0.5, Ni9Cu1, Ni7Cu3, Ni5Cu5, and Ni3Cu7. The fourth set included samples loaded with 10 wt. % of Ni with additional loading of Cu (1, 5, 10 wt. %). Samples were denoted as Ni10Cu1, Ni10Cu5, Ni10Cu10. The fifth set included reference samples of CuO, NiO, NiAl2O4 and Al2O3. All Ni- and Cu-containing catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method using metal nitrates as a metal precursor and alumina as a support. To reach the desired loading (Table 1 ), the measured quantity of nitrate salts (Ni(NO3)2·3H2O supplied from Carl Roth Germany and/or Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Penta s.r.o.) was dissolved in water and the appropriate amount of alumina (ɣ-Al2O3, granules: mesh 300/155, Sasol Germany) was added. Then, water was evaporated under vacuum and the sample was dried at 120 °C for 5 h and calcined at 350 °C for 5 h. NiO was prepared by the calcination of Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O at 350 °C for 5 h, while CuO was prepared by the calcination of Cu(NO3)2 at 350 °C for 3 h. NiAl2O4 was prepared by the method described by Cesteros et al. [29]. In brief, Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (Lach-Ner Czech Republic) in Ni-to-Al molar ratio of 1-to-2 were co-precipitated by slow addition of 1 M solution of NH4(OH) (Lach-Ner Czech Republic). The precipitate was filtered, dried at 100 °C, and calcined at 700 °C or 900°as denoted in the name. 2.2 Characterization of catalyst All catalysts, their precursors and reference materials were characterized by different techniques. Phase composition was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy, chemical composition by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) or X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), surface area by N2 physisorption (SBET), copper metal surface area by N2O reactive frontal chromatography (RFC), nickel metal surface area by hydrogen pulse chemisorption, reducibility by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), acidity by ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), hydrogen adsorption capacity by hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and organics (anisole, guaiacol, furfuryl alcohol) adsorption/desorption by breakthrough curve measurement and TPD. For evaluation of the number and type of residual carbonaceous species on spent catalyst samples (after organics adsorption and subsequent TPD) temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was applied. Details of all procedures are given in Supplementary Materials. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Chemical composition and structural-textural analysis of prepared catalysts In this work, different Ni and Cu loadings were targeted to be deposited using the wet impregnation method. To determine the actual catalyst composition XRF or ICP-MS were used (Table 1). The crystalline phases and NiO or CuO particle sizes were determined in calcined catalysts using XRD. Fig. 1 a shows the recorded XRD patterns, highlighting the typical reflections of NiO (JCPDS card 00–004–0835), CuO (JCPDS card 00–041–0254), and alumina (JCPDS card 00–001–1303). Comparing the reference samples NiO and NiAl2O4 −700, NiAl2O4–900 and Al2O3 several shifts in the XRD patterns were noticeable, with some overlaps. The largest differences were observed in the regions of 2θ=50–55° and 2θ=74–80° In Ni/Al2O3 samples, NiO started to be detectable when NiO content exceeded approximately 10 wt. %, this indicates either the low crystallinity of NiO phase or the small particle size. Compared to NiAl2O4–700 and NiAl2O4–900 samples, no peak broadening of Ni/Al2O4 samples in the region 2θ=74–80°, which is typical for the spinel, was detected. This indicates that i) its bulk presence is rather unlikely, or ii) its presence might occur only on the surface, but it is below the detection limit. A similar observation was obtained for CuO, which started to be detectable at concentrations around 7 wt. %. Additionally, the particle size was evaluated for the NiO (200) crystalline plane at 2θ = 50.8°, which does not interfere with the reflections of alumina. The particle size of unsupported NiO was 82 nm, while the interaction of NiO with Al2O3 resulted in particles smaller than 6 nm after deposition. The particle size of CuO was difficult to estimate due to its low concentration, but for the sample Cu10, it was 9 nm (Table 1). The Raman spectra are shown in Fig. 1 b The spectra of unsupported NiO exhibited the typical band of the longitudinal optical (LO) mode of Ni-O stretching vibration [30], with maxima at 500 cm-1. This peak is composed of two specific bands at 500 and 460 cm-1, corresponding to crystalline NiO particles and the octahedral coordination of Ni [31]. However, when NiO was deposited on the surface of alumina, the LO mode band shifted towards 530–550 cm-1, and no bands at 200 or 375 cm-1 for spinel appeared. This shift was due to the formation of well-dispersed, non-uniform and strongly bonded NiO particles on the alumina Al2O3 called NiO-like phase. Typically, NiAl2O4 spinel shows bands at 200, 375 and 600 cm-1,when Ni occupies both octahedral and tetrahedral positions, indicating an inverted spinel structure [32]. Only the sample NiAl2O3–900 indicated the presence of spinel structure at 375 cm-1 [31,33] and other peaks are under the level of detection Unfortunately, its intensity is very low, therefore, it is not possible to exclude the contribution of that phase in Ni samples. Additionally, the Raman spectra of Cu-containing catalysts showed a slight shift towards higher Raman frequencies, suggesting possible partial Cu substitution of Ni with Cu [34]. XPS was used to investigate the catalyst surface composition. The Ni 2p binding energy region (Fig. 2 a) was used to evaluate the nature of Ni species. In that region, a significant difference in 2p3/2 region (2.3 eV) between the main peak positions of NiO and NiAl2O4 reference samples was observed. Since the peak maxima of our samples were shifted by 2.3 eV towards lower binding energy, it indicates the presence of spinel-like species in all the samples [35]. NiO was confirmed in Ni10Cu5 and Ni10Cu10 samples and possibly in Ni10Cu1, however, in samples with total metal loading of 10 wt. %, the surface indicated rather spinel-like species. Thus, the formation of NiO surface can be connected with increased metal loading. No evidence for the presence of Ni species with an oxidation state of 3+ was observed in either the XRD or XPS data. The surface area of in-situ reduced samples was measured using nitrogen physisorption. The surface area linearly decreased with increasing metal loading (Fig. 2 b). The metal loading of 5 wt. % resulted in a decrease from 220 to 180 m2·g-1 and loadings above 10 wt. % caused drops even to 160–140 m2·g-1. 3.2 Reducibility 3.2.1 Monometallic Ni catalysts The reducibility of prepared materials was investigated using H2-TPR. Fig. 3 shows the reduction profile of monometallic Ni/Al2O3 samples, indicating several overlapping peaks. This suggests that Ni exists in various oxide forms, interacting differently with alumina. Five different species were observed [36] (Fig. 3 a): (type 0) residual nickel nitrate reducible at temperature around 250 °C, (I) free NiO representing species weakly or not at all interacting with the alumina support, (II) nickel-enriched mixed oxide phase (NiO-like), (III) Al-enriched mixed oxide phase (NiAl2O4-like), and (IV) nickel aluminate. The position and shape of the reduction peak of NiO reference sample differed compared to NiO peak (I) in Ni/Al2O3 samples. TPR profile of NiO reference sample seems to be composed of two peaks, however, these are rather resulting from diffusion limitations in the bulky NiO structure with high Ni loading then from the presence of different structures, since the reduction of nickel oxide is referred to as one step reduction process [37,38]. Therefore, for our supported samples with much lower Ni loadings, a simple TPR profile is expected. The shifted position of NiO peak observed in supported samples is due to the NiO interaction with alumina and different NiO structures [39,40] as suggested by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 1 b). It was proven by XRD that the NiO particle size of supported NiO was smaller (3–11 nm) compared to bulk NiO, and thus, the shift of peak I to lower temperatures can be observed. Similarly, a small difference in the position of peak IV, reflecting differences between bulk NiAl2O4 and supported NiAl2O4, can be noticed, however, the trend is opposite to NiO (T max of bulk phase < T max of supported phase). This is given by the fact, that the spinel phase formed on the support is dispersed (non-continuous) and even possibly covered by NiO and NiO-like species and thus less accessible and harder to reduce. In Ni/Al2O3 samples, the peak I maximum was at the highest temperature for Ni6 having the largest NiO particle size. Generally, the amount of these free NiO species was very low compared to the other types of Ni species (Figure S1). No type II species (NiO-like) were detected in Ni6; these species began to appear with increasing Ni content (Fig. 3 a, Figure S1). The most abundant phases were types II and III, and their amount increased with increasing Ni content. NiAl2O4-like species (type III) were rather present than NiO-like species, but their mutual distribution changed with Ni content. This was in line with other publications [41–43]. Interestingly, the abundance of type II and III species seemed to approach a constant value for Ni loading 14–15 wt. % (Figure S1). It suggests that there might exist a certain limitation for the formation of NiO-like and NiAl2O4-like species, which can be determined by the Al2O3 – Ni interface and thus governed by the alumina surface area as well as Ni loading. Also, spinel species appear to be limited by some characteristics of the alumina support, since a constant amount of NiAl2O4 was determined for all catalysts. Additionally, the presence of residual nitrates (region 0) was confirmed by monitoring the MS signal at m/z = 28, 30, and 44 during H2-TPR (Table S1-S3). These signals were identified in Ni6, Ni10, and Ni14 samples, and they overlapped with the region 0 in H2-TPR profile. With increasing Ni content, the Ni nitrate reduction peak moved to lower temperatures and nitrate amounts reached zero in Ni16. One can speculate that if the nitrates are in closer contact with the support surface (rather than with the formed surface Ni species such as NiO or NiAl2O4), they need a higher calcination temperature to be completely decomposed. Anyway, the presence of residual nitrates resulted in the overestimation of the calculated H2 consumption due to the nitrate group reduction. Therefore, Table 2 shows data uncorrected as well as corrected for nitrates presence. The degree of reduction (at 480 °C) was calculated to reach values approx. 40 - 70 % (Table 2). The deviation from a complete reduction was attributed to the presence of primarily type IV Ni particles, which required higher reduction temperature. Therefore, an additional H2-TPR was performed at 800 °C (Table 2) that should be sufficient to reduce also the spinel phase. Indeed, the reduction degree increased close to 100 %, however, it was expected that NiO particles significantly sintered. 3.2.2 Monometallic Cu catalysts The reduction profiles of Cu/Al2O3 samples consisted of several overlapping peaks in the range of 150 - 400 °C (Fig. 3 b). Three types of Cu species were observed: well-dispersed CuO (A), CuO-bulk (B), and either isolated Cu2+ species strongly interacting with the support or surface CuAl2O4-like (C) phase [44,45]. In line with the Ni catalysts, the presence of residual nitrates was confirmed (Figure S2, Fig. 3 b, Table S2) and the estimated reduction degree was corrected by the elimination of hydrogen consumed for nitrate group reduction (Table 2). Figure S3 shows that at very low Cu loadings isolated Cu2+ strongly interacting with support (type C) and dispersed CuO species (A) were formed. As the Cu loading increased, the formation of type C phase was suppressed, probably due to its transformation into CuO phase and/or due to coverage by newly formed CuO phase. However, the presence of highly dispersed Cu2+ species (type C) was observed in all our samples, although its area was small. This means that all samples contained a low amount of highly dispersed species interacting strongly with the support. At the same time, the number of dispersed CuO species gradually increased up to the point where bulk CuO was formed. A spontaneous separation of the reduction profile to distinct peaks of A and B species was observed in the case of Cu10 only, as the formation of A and B species typically depends on the Cu loading [46,47]. The intensity of the peak corresponding to the A-type species increased and the peak position shifted towards lower temperature as the Cu content increased. The shift of A-type peak towards higher temperatures with decreasing loading was caused by increased Cu dispersion due to the low amount of Cu. As a result, the Cu phase was most probably transformed into the isolated Cu2+ ions strongly interacting with the support or even possibly the formation of non-stoichiometric surface copper aluminate [44,47–49]. The same phenomenon was noticed in XRD, when CuO particles were detected only in Cu10. Therefore, the well-dispersed CuO particles (type A) might be of size < 3 nm [50]and just those of type B can be observed in XRD. 3.2.3 Bimetallic catalysts The reduction profiles of bimetallic samples (Fig. 4 , Figure S4) revealed several overlapping peaks including those attributed to the reduction of residual nitrates (Figure S5). Similar to monometallic Ni samples, reduction at 480 °C did not ensure the complete reduction of all Ni species. The mutual influence of both metals on reducibility, expressed as the corrected degree of reduction, is summarized in Table 2. The correction was based on the results obtained for monometallic samples regarding nitrate presence. The degree of reduction of bimetallic samples containing 10 wt. % metals decreased with the increasing Ni loading, however, the presence of Cu increased compared to monometallic Ni samples the degree of Ni reduction by approximately 15 −20 % (Figure S7) in samples containing up to 7 wt. % of Ni. For samples with 8 and 10 wt. % of Ni, Cu had negligible influence on Ni reducibility (green and black points follow the orange line in Figure S7). Moreover, when the Ni content exceeded 10 wt. %, higher Cu loading (>5 wt. %) suppressed Ni reducibility. This indicated that the influence of Cu on Ni reducibility depended on the total metal loading. At lower total metal loadings, Cu had a positive effect, while at higher loadings, Ni might be covered by Cu, hindering its reduction. In the H2-TPR patterns, characteristic peaks II and III, associated with NiO-like and surface NiAl2O4-like species, respectively, were identified and decreased with the decreasing Ni content (Fig. 4 a). Additionally, a sharp peak attributed to well-dispersed Cu species of A-type and, in samples with Cu content > 5 wt. %, also B-type species were identified as well at T < 300 °C. The A-type peak shifted towards lower temperatures as the Ni-to-Cu ratio decreased. This confirms the suggestion that CuO can enhance the reducibility of NiO after it is reduced. Comparing samples with the same Cu amount (1 and 5 wt. %) but different Ni loading, the A-type peak shifted towards lower temperatures with the addition of Ni (Fig. 5 ), but only if bulk CuO species were not formed (This was observed <5 wt. % Cu loading in bimetallic samples). Compared to the monometallic samples (Fig. 3), bulk CuO species formed at lower Cu loading (5 vs. 7 wt. %), likely due to the surface coverage by both Ni and Cu species, leaving less space for Cu dispersion. Since the surface is covered by both metals, the formation of a bulky phase is expected to occur earlier (at lower loading) than when only Cu is placed on the surface. The effect of adding small amounts of Ni to Cu causing Cu segregation on catalyst surface, has also been published in the literature [51]. The effect of Ni and Cu in bimetallic samples was mutual. As Cu loading increased, the Ni peak III shifted to lower temperatures (Fig. 4 b, Figure S4) and the area of peak I increased. Additionally, a new type of Ni species was formed, which was reduced in the low-temperature region, manifested as peak A. Notably, the area of peak A was significantly larger than expected if only copper was reduced. Therefore, this reduction peak A represents the simultaneous reduction of Cu and Ni. The finding aligns well with literature where this phase is generally attributed to NiO interacting with CuO [52], but the most frequent explanation is the alloying of Cu and Ni during hydrogen treatment [53]. These interactions were responsible for the changes in Ni reduction degree described above (Table 2, Figure S7). 3.3 Acidity (NH3-TPD) NH3-TPD was used to describe the acid properties of studied materials. Ni-containing samples with reduced Ni species have two distinct types of acid sites (denoted as A and B, Table S4). As reported previously [2], only molecular adsorption of ammonia was observed on alumina support (sites A), while adsorption followed by NH3 dissociation during heating up occurred on reduced Ni sites, resulting in N2 and H2 (sites B). Both sites can be considered as Lewis acid sites, however, those formed on alumina support are determined from NH3 desorption, while Ni0 species responsible for NH3 dissociative adsorption are estimated from the amount of nitrogen evolved during ammonia decomposition, following the stoichiometry (two moles of NH3 yield one mole of N2). Ammonia decomposition on Ni sites is a well-known feature as Ni-based catalysts have been used for ammonia decomposition for several decades [54,55]. Although H2 desorption occurred in two peaks, N2 desorption happened in a single peak. Similar behaviour was observed for all Ni-containing catalysts (both monometallic and bimetallic), whereas samples loaded solely with Cu showed no N2 evolution (Fig. 6 ). H2 evolution was significantly higher for Ni-loaded samples than for Cu monometallic samples producing negligible amounts of H2 above 500 °C. Blank experiments without NH3 adsorption confirmed (Fig. 6 b, grey lines) that hydrogen evolved above 500 °C was residual hydrogen from the reduction pre-treatment rather than the product of NH3 decomposition. More residual hydrogen was observed for bimetallic samples compared to monometallic ones. The total number of evolved H2 and N2 was independent of Cu content but was strongly influenced by the presence of Ni (Figure S8) indicating that NH3 decomposition occurred exclusively on Ni sites. However, the profile of H2 evolution (Fig. 6, Figure S9) varied depending not only on Ni loading (increasing intensity with Ni loading), but also on Cu loading (more flat profile with increasing Cu loading), likely reflecting the properties of Ni-Cu alloy species formed during reduction pre-treatment and observed in H2-TPR or possibly due to coverage of Ni by Cu, thus lowering its surface accessibility. The number of NH3 adsorbed without subsequent dissociation (acid sites A) was lower compared to neat Al2O3 and subsequently decreased with increasing total metal loading (Table S4, Fig. 7 ). This correlated with the decrease in the catalyst specific surface area (Fig. 2 b), as Ni and/or Cu cover part of the surface. The distribution of acid sites strength (NH3 signal, Fig. 6) was similar for all the catalysts and the alumina support. NH3 desorption peaks were observed throughout the temperate range tested (100 - 480 °C), indicating the presence of various types of sites, i.e. sites of different acid strength. 3.4 Metal surface area (H2 chemisorption and N2O reactive frontal chromatography) 3.4.1 H2 chemisorption The nickel surface area was determined using the H2 chemisorption method (Table S5), since hydrogen adsorbs on nickel but not on copper [56]. To assess the effect of the degree of reduction on the active Ni surface area, H2 uptake was compared for Ni monometallic catalysts reduced at different temperatures (480 and 800 °C). It was found (Figure S10) that when the degree of reduction exceeded 50 % and the catalyst contained >6 wt. % Ni, H2 uptake remained constant, even with a higher degree of reduction. This suggests that once the reduction surpasses a certain threshold (> 50 %), nearly all surface species are reduced at temperatures below 500 °C, making these samples suitable for nickel surface area determination by pulse chemisorption. In other words, species reduced at higher temperatures are likely sub-surface species and do not contribute to surface hydrogen adsorption, as they might be covered by another surface layer that is reducible at lower temperatures In the studied Ni-containing catalysts (Table 2), all samples either contain >6 wt. % of Ni and were reduced to a degree > 50 %, or contain a lower Ni amount with a reduction degree > 50 % under given conditions (480 °C + 1 h isotherm) except for Ni6. Therefore, it was expected that only this sample may provide biased results (difference between surface area obtained on samples reduced at 480 and 800 °C), as confirmed in Fig. 8 a, where the number of Ni metal species available on the surface increased with increasing Ni loading in monometallic samples. Nonetheless, the effect of reduction temperature (compare the position of blue and orange points in Fig. 8a) was more pronounced with decreasing loading being the biggest in Ni6. A smaller difference was observed for Ni10, while it was negligible in Ni16. In the case of NiAl2O4, a large deviation was observed for both reduction temperatures, as predicted from H2-TPR measurements. Thus, low loadings and different phase compositions can strongly affect H2 pulse chemisorption results. The number of accessible Ni on the surface (m2/gsample) also increased with Ni content in bimetallic Ni-Cu samples reduced at 480 °C, except for Ni10Cu10. This exception could be attributed to its decreased total surface area (Table 1) and/or potential coverage of Ni by Cu species. Additionally, the presence of Cu had an impact on the Ni surface area. Catalysts with low Ni and high Cu loading (Ni3Cu7, Ni5Cu5) showed a higher-than-expected Ni surface area compared to the other bimetallic samples reduced at 480 °C. This increase could be due to enhanced reducibility and/or the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy phase, as suggested by H2-TPR. However, when these two samples were fully reduced at 800 °C, the Ni surface area significantly decreased, probably because of the sintering of the bimetallic phase due to alloying effects. When the overall Ni surface area was normalized per Ni loading, i.e. expressed as Ni specific surface area (m2/gNi), similar trends were observed. Fig. 8 b shows that the Ni specific surface area slightly decreased with Ni loading in fully reduced (800 °C) monometallic samples, while the opposite trend was observed for samples reduced at 480 °C, reflecting their increasing reduction degree. Therefore, chemisorption results expressed as the Ni surface area (m2 Ni/gNi) are much more sensitive to the reduction degree than when expressed in terms of sample accessibility (m2 Ni/gsample). In bimetallic samples reduced at 480 °C, the dispersion decreased, but the trend differed from that of monometallic samples. A sharp change around 7 wt. % of Ni clearly indicates the influence of Cu on Ni reducibility and Ni surface accessibility. It is important to note that Cu caused two opposing effects. On the one hand, Cu enhanced the degree of Ni reduction, thereby, increasing the amount of chemisorbed hydrogen. On the other hand, in samples with the total metal loading of 10 wt. %, Ni content decreased with increase in Cu loading and in samples with 10 wt. % Ni, the increasing amount of added Cu may block the Ni surface and hence both effects resulted in lower H2 uptake. Furthermore, Cu can interact with Ni (as indicated by peak A in H2-TPR for bimetallic samples), and alloy formation may induce a spillover effect [57], potentially leading to overestimated hydrogen uptake. Therefore, a clear Cu effect was observed only in samples with low Ni loading, where total metal surface did not play a significant role (up to 5 %), despite uncertainty about whether increased H2 uptake was due to a spillover or increased Ni availability boosted by Cu presence and new phase formation in reduced samples. In summary, it was estimated that the exposed alumina surface should accommodate 10 % of the Ni species (Table S6). Since the amount of NiO observed in H2-TPR is less than this (Figure S1), it is likely that part of the surface also contains reducible NiO-like or NiAl2O4-like species in addition to NiO. 3.4.2 Reactive frontal chromatography - N2O chemisorption Reactive chemisorption of N2O (RFC) was employed for the determination of Cu surface area using N2O as a selective probe molecule for metallic Cu [58], however, the obtained results strongly depended on the reduction temperature used. Monometallic Cu samples, when not fully reduced, exhibited low Cu surface area, while using high temperatures (higher than those needed for reduction) ensured better reduction of Cu species, but this also induced the sintering effect. Since the required reduction temperature increased with decreasing Cu loading (see part 3.2 Reducibility), the Cu surface area showed a volcano-type dependence (Fig. 9 a). The profile was sharper and the maxima shifted to higher temperatures with higher Cu content, indicating that 200 °C was sufficient to reduce the samples with higher loading, while for low-loaded samples, RFC after reduction at 200 °C yielded zero values. Conversely, the reduction at 480 °C ensured a high specific Cu surface area for low-loaded samples. In contrast, the measured Cu surface area decreased for highly loaded samples due to sintering and agglomeration occurring more readily than in samples with highly diluted Cu species. This is due to the fact that species in more dilute systems can interact more strongly with support than those in large particles where the surface Cu is less affected by the alumina surface. The evaluation of Cu surface area in bimetallic samples was complicated since reduced Ni can also chemisorb N2O, however, without known stoichiometry [59], as was also verified in a separate test. Ni -loaded samples reduced at >200 °C chemisorbed N2O (Table S7, Ni14) which resulted in a deviation in Cu surface area in bimetallic samples (Fig. 9 b). In summary, the specific Cu surface area decreased with Cu loading (Fig. 10 a), while its accessibility on the surface increased (Fig. 10 b). Fig. 10 a shows two regions, where the blue region represents properly reduced samples, while the rest are samples reduced at unsuitable temperature (either too low or too high), thus Cu surface area in those samples was underestimated or lowered due sintering effects. The underestimation increased with decreasing Cu loading in monometallic samples if compared with bimetallic catalyst with the same Cu loading. 3.5 Hydrogen desorption (H2-TPD) As demonstrated by H2 pulse chemisorption measurements, H2 uptake and subsequent release during H2-TPD should exhibit dependence on metal composition. Bare alumina did not adsorb neither desorb any hydrogen during H2-TPD (Fig. 11 a) as indicated by the absence of hydrogen uptake during H₂ pulses. Also, a mostly flat profile, with a little hydrogen adsorption/desorption below 200 °C and above 400 °C, was detected in Cu10. In Ni-containing catalysts, the TPD profiles varied with the Ni content (Fig. 11 a) and four maxima at around 100, 200, 400 and above 450 °C (peaks 1–4) were found. Those peaks indicated various sites capable of H₂ adsorption associated with different adsorption states of hydrogen related to the morphology and size of Ni particles, as well as the support and/or Cu species, considering the potential spillover from Ni to Al₂O₃ or Cu [57]. Typically, literature ascribes H2 from spillover to peaks above 230 °C [60,61] for supported catalysts. However, based on other literature findings [62] and our observations (Fig. 11 b), we have proposed that not all of the hydrogen released above 230 °C was due to the spillover. It may originate from the pre-treatment reduction process, where residual hydrogen was accumulated in the subsurface layers and consequently evolved at temperatures above those used for sample cleaning after reduction. A similar feature was also observed during NH3-TPD where residual hydrogen was released during TPD (Fig. 6 b). Therefore, the peak above 480 °C (here used as a reduction and cleaning pre-treatment temperature) was attributed to the residual hydrogen from the reduction process. This suggestion was supported by the data shown in recent publication [2], where the amount of hydrogen desorbed during H2-TPD below 450 °C was equal to the amount of hydrogen adsorbed during pulse chemisorption. The finding was also confirmed by measurements, where cleaning in Ar was performed at 600 °C, resulting in the absence of peak 4 and also by blank test (H2-TPD without H2 adsorption step), where H2 evolution was clearly observed above 480 °C (Fig. 11 b, green line vs. grey line). Peak 3 in Fig. 11 a increased with increasing Ni loading and shifted to higher temperatures with increasing Cu loading in bimetallic samples. The comparison of samples reduced at 480 °C (partially reduced species) and at 800 °C (fully reduced) (Fig. 11 b and Figure S11) shows a decrease in peak 3 with an increasing degree of reduction. Therefore, based on literature [63], we attributed peak 3 to the spillover process as it can only occur in the presence of the Ni0/Ni+ couple, and therefore, the volume of H2 involved in the redox spillover should decrease and approach zero as the extent of reduction increases. The assignment of peaks 2 to reduced Ni species, specifically hydrogen adsorption on Ni species obtained by the reduction of NiO and NiO-like and/or spinel-like structures (peak 2a vs. 2b, Fig. 11 a) follows from these observations: (i) NiO amount increases with increasing Ni loading in monometallic samples (Fig. 3 a). NiO species were not confirmed by H2-TPR in Ni5Cu5, therefore peak 2a is missing in Fig. 11 a, while Ni10Cu1, Ni10Cu5 and Ni10Cu10 possess peak 2a in accordance with H2-TPR results (Figure S4, peak I). (ii) NiO-like species were observed in H2-TPR only on monometallic Ni samples loaded with Ni ≥ 10 wt. % and amounts of spinel-like species significantly increased with increasing loading (Fig. 3 , Figure S1). Therefore, in the H2-TPD spectrum of Ni14, the broadening of peak 2 at higher temperatures was clearly observed compared to Ni10 (Fig. 11 a). (iii) For bimetallic samples, Cu presence suppressed spinel-like species formation (Fig. 4), which resulted in the disappearance of peak 2b in Fig. 11 a in bimetallic samples. Interestingly, the additional temperature treatment (Fig. 11 b) at or above the reduction temperature influenced the areas of peaks 2 and 3 when the amount of desorbed hydrogen was lower. This decrease was attributed to a reduction in total surface area (the S BET value measured on the sample cleaned at 600 °C after H2-TPD was 151 m2/g compared to 183 m2/g for Ni10 in Table 1) and/or surface Ni phase sintering. Here it must be considered that cleaning is done on the reduced sample, thus much more prone to sintering then in case of oxidic form. The temperature used (600 °C) was higher than the Tammann temperature of Ni (590 °C) [64] - the point at which atoms in a bulk crystal lattice become sufficiently mobile to diffuse readily, making it the temperature at which atoms in a solid material are more susceptible to recrystallization, agglomeration, or sintering[65]. Besides the decrease in peak areas, the changes in the shape of peak 2 after high-temperature treatment at 800 °C were observed - an increase in peak 2a area was accompanied by a decrease in the peak 2b area. We suppose that severe thermal treatment could cause not only a surface area decrease but also result in a rearrangement of the NiO-like and spinel-like species into NiO. When Ni10 was reduced at 800 °C, we noted an increase in the peak 4 area compared to the blank test in Ar (Fig. 11b). This increase in peak 4 area suggests that hydrogen was adsorbed on the reduced spinel nickel species. In contrast, at lower temperatures, the spinel phases remained unreduced and therefore did not adsorb hydrogen. Additionally, the area of peak 1 increased with higher Cu loading for bimetallic samples. However, the underlying mechanism is not clear. Low-temperature peaks are commonly ascribed to molecular non-dissociative adsorption [66]. If this is the case, hydrogen adsorption may occur on Ni and Cu species that are more available due to the formation of different types of Ni-Cu phases (e.g. alloys confirmed in H2-TPR). However, it is also plausible that it may originate from the spillover process from reduced nickel particles to copper species [63], although in this case the peak temperature seems too low. Nonetheless, this observation indicates that the presence of Cu in bimetallic catalysts can enhance hydrogen adsorption. Therefore, H2-TPD results provided information about (i) the adsorption of hydrogen on Ni metallic phases (low-temperature region below 300 °C, peak 2), (ii) the effect of Cu on hydrogen adsorption in bimetallic samples, (iii) H2 storage due to spillover caused by the presence of Ni in both reduced and unreduced forms[63] (mid-temperature region of 300–450 °C, peak 3) and (iv) H2 storage in the subsurface regions (high-temperature region above 400 °C, peak 4), (v) H2 adsorption on reduced spinel species (high-temperature region, peak 4). In summary, the H2-TPD results indicate that the use of pulse chemisorption for the Ni surface area determination, especially in bimetallic catalysts, is very challenging and complex. This method may be biased by the presence of unreduced Ni species if experimental conditions are not meticulously controlled. 3.6 Adsorption capacity for organics (anisole, guaiacol, furfuryl alcohol) The adsorption capacity and adsorption-desorption characteristics of studied materials were investigated on the model compounds: anisole, guaiacol, and furfuryl alcohol. Adsorption capacity was evaluated at 36 °C by breakthrough curve measurements of organics balanced by inert gas. More strongly adsorbed species were studied using TPD and TPO methods. Adsorption tests with one specific feed concentration were performed for all samples (anisole approx. 1400 ppm, guaiacol approx. 140 ppm, furfuryl alcohol approx. 450 ppm), while the effect of feed concentration was performed using Ni10, Cu10 and Al2O3. The number of adsorbed organic species increased slightly with increasing acidity (Fig. 12 ) and, corresponded to the decrease in metal loading and the increase in total surface area (Fig. 2 , Figure S12). Therefore, the highest adsorption capacity was consistently observed for pure alumina. Among the tested organics, the increase in adsorption capacity was more pronounced for furfuryl alcohol than for anisole and guaiacol. A steeper increase in furfuryl alcohol adsorption was observed for Cu-containing catalysts than for Ni catalysts. The calculated adsorption capacity was highly dependent on the concentration of organic compounds used during the adsorption (Fig. 13 , Figure S13). At lower feed concentrations (typically <200 ppm), the adsorbed amount increased steeply with the growth in the organic’s concentration, while at higher concentrations it reached a plateau, i.e. the adsorbed amount did not further increase with the growing concentration of the organics in the feed. Unfortunately, testing at even higher concentrations was not feasible due to the high boiling points of the organic compounds. For Ni10 (Fig. 13 a) the highest adsorption capacity was observed for furfuryl alcohol (approx. 0.95 mmol/g), slightly lower for guaiacol (approx. 0.8 mmol/g) and the lowest for anisole (approx. 0.25 mmol/g) if it is compared for the same initial concentration used during adsorption - 200 ppm. Similar trends were observable also for Cu10 and Al2O3. A concentration dependence is expected if the adsorption proceeds by physisorption, whereas the adsorbed amount by chemisorption should be limited by the number of accessible active sites. The data suggest that a combination of both adsorption modes is likely for these samples, as the adsorption trends approach a plateau. This dual-mode behaviour was further supported by the detection of weakly adsorbed species during the sample cleaning with inert gas flow between adsorption and TPD steps (Figure S13). The desorbed quantities are illustrated in Fig. 13. The adsorbed species that do not desorb at 36 °C were desorbed during subsequent heating (TPD). Notably, the number of adsorbed molecules for all tested organic compounds was approximately 10 times higher than the number of species desorbed during TPD (Table S8). The relationship between the number of desorbed species during TPD and the metal loading varied distinctly depending on the organic compound studied (Fig. 14 ). For guaiacol, no significant dependence on metal loading or chemical composition was observed. In contrast, for anisole, the desorbed quantity decreased with increasing metal loading, up to a threshold of 10 - 15 wt. %, beyond which it stabilized. For furfuryl alcohol desorption strongly correlated with Cu loading but remained unaffected by the presence of Ni. Higher Cu loading increased the total desorbed quantity of furfuryl alcohol with additional enhancement observed in bimetallic Ni-Cu samples (e.g., Ni5Cu5). This synergistic effect was attributed to mutual interactions and potential alloying of Ni and Cu, as indicated by H2-TPR. The lower desorbed amount of furfuryl alcohol observed in Ni10Cu10 (Fig. 14 c) was attributed to its significantly reduced total surface area and thus the lowest number of acid sites. This effect of Cu aligns with DFT calculation [67] suggesting that furfuryl alcohol preferentially adsorbs on Al sites adjacent to Cu clusters. Cu catalysts are well-studied for furfural hydrogenation due to their excellent activity towards the reduction of the aldehyde group [68] indicating appropriate adsorption sites formed by Cu species. Therefore, the interface between Al sites of the support and the Cu clusters appears crucial for furfuryl alcohol adsorption, while favourable sites for H2 dissociations are distinct, as demonstrated by H2-TPD and NH3-TPD. The observed differences (Fig. 14) suggested that guaiacol, which desorbed during TPD, was adsorbed on sites unaffected by metal deposition, likely alumina sites not taking part in metal anchoring (site I). On the other hand, anisole desorption during TPD indicated the involvement of two types of sites – the first one similar to those adsorbing guaiacol (site I) and the second one, whose availability varied with metal loading (site II). The decline in desorbed amount of anisole with increasing metal loading suggested that sites II (initially located on alumina) became covered by deposited metals. As a result, sites II were available as adsorption sites for anisole only in samples with low metal loading - below 10 wt. %. TPD analysis of furfuryl alcohol revealed its adsorption primarily on-site I. However, in the presence of Cu, additional sites (site III) were formed, enhancing adsorption capacity. The organics concentration in the feed did not affect the number of species desorbed during TPD (Figure S14). The desorption of organics during TPD was accompanied by the evolution of lighter molecules that were formed either due to dissociative adsorption of the model compounds or rather by surface reaction at the desorption conditions. Anisole was an exception, as its desorption was not accompanied by surface reactions yielding organic species. In case of guaiacol TPD, methanol and dimethoxybenzene were detected (Fig. 15 ), while in case of furfuryl alcohol TPD, traces of methyl furan, furfural and furan were detected. Although the desorption temperatures of unreacted anisole, guaiacol, and furfuryl alcohol were consistent across all samples, the composition-temperature dependent evolution of reactive products was observed suggesting that unreacted model compounds desorbed during TPD were adsorbed on the alumina support (site I), while reactive products appeared to interact with or be bound/stabilized by the alumina-metal interface. Besides organic molecules, decomposition products such as H2, CO2, CO, and CH4 were detected during TPD. Their appearance and temperature of their release depended on the sample composition (Fig. 16 – 18). The hydrogen desorption profiles for Ni10 varied significantly depending on the pre-adsorbed organics. While no hydrogen was formed during anisole TPD (Fig. 16), H2 evolution was observed during guaiacol (Fig. 17 ) and furfuryl alcohol TPD (Fig. 18 ), suggesting they underwent dehydrogenation. However, the shapes of their hydrogen desorption profiles differed, indicating different temperature windows of their transformation/dehydrogenation. The hydrogen desorption profile for Ni10 during guaiacol desorption closely resembled H2-TPD profile shown in Fig. 11 a, particularly peaks 3 and 4 corresponding to H2 spillover and desorption from reduced spinel species or residual hydrogen from reduction pre-treatment. However, the blank test (i.e., TPD on a reduced and cleaned sample without organics adsorption, not shown) showed no peak for residual hydrogen, ruling out this possibility. Therefore, the peak around 500 °C (Fig. 17 a) likely represents hydrogen desorbed from the reduced spinel phase. Since dimethoxybenzene evolved at lower temperatures and the hydrogen profile shape for Ni10 matched that of H2-TPD, the dehydrogenation must occur below the temperatures required for H2 desorption, i.e., below 300 °C. In this case, the hydrogen is captured on the surface via spillover between reduced and unreduced nickel species and via adsorption on the reduced spinel phases. In contrast, furfuryl alcohol TPD exhibited a single broad hydrogen peak above 300 °C. This suggested that dehydrogenation occurred directly at this temperature with no significant surface retention. The detection of trace amounts of furan in this temperature region supports the hypothesis that the reactive conversion of furfuryl alcohol begins only above 250–300 °C. Hydrogen evolution was also observed for furfuryl alcohol (Fig. 18) and guaiacol (Fig. 17) on Cu10 and even on Al2O3, but to a much lesser extent and at higher temperatures. During furfuryl alcohol, anisole, and guaiacol TPD, CO₂ was formed on Ni10 and Cu10, whereas on alumina, CO₂ was only observed during furfuryl alcohol TPD (Fig. 16 – 18). CO evolution occurred exclusively on Ni10 during furfuryl alcohol and guaiacol TPD, though in very small quantities (Figure S15). Additionally, traces of CH4 were detected only on alumina during furfuryl alcohol TPD, while methanol evolution was detected only during guaiacol TPD on Ni10, Cu10 and Al2O3 (Fig. 16 – 18). Organics TPD data are very scarce in the literature and to the best of our knowledge, no such data was published for anisole and furfuryl alcohol on alumina-based catalysts; the existing studies focused mostly on SiO2-based samples [19,69,70]. For example, Mark et al. [70] have reported temperature-programmed desorption experiments of furfuryl alcohol on silica modified with Pd. DFT calculations showed a change in the desorption temperature of reactive products due to weakened adsorption of reaction intermediates, including atomic hydrogen. Also, other literature shows that anisole and guaiacol are not only adsorbed and desorbed but also undergo hydrogenolysis or conversion through demethoxylation and dehydroxylation, yielding benzene on SiO2 support [69] or Ni/SiO2 [19]. Simultaneous evolution of anisole and CO, CH4 and H2 was reported in [19] (anisole TPD), while in [69] guaiacol desorption was also accompanied by anisole, phenol and catechol formation (guaiacol TPD). Furfuryl alcohol TPD on SiO2 resulted in additional evolution of H2O, CO and methyl furan, while for Pd-based catalysts also furan, propane, propylene and furfural were detected [70,71]. Cu and Ni/Cu metal surfaces yielded during furfuryl alcohol TPD methyl furan, furfural and unselective decomposition products (CO, H2 and Cads) [72]. Guaiacol TPD was shown only for sulfided NiMo oxides/Al2O3 and Al2O3 [73], but no accompanying products were mentioned in the study. In contrast to [19] and [73], where anisole and guaiacol were desorbed in a wide temperature range 100–700 °C, in our case desorption of all three tested organics stopped at about 200 °C similarly to [69,70]. Valuable insights into organics TPD and interpretation of their results can be obtained from spectroscopic studies explaining modes of adsorption and their changes during heating. It was demonstrated by FTIR [74], that furfuryl alcohol is the predominant adsorbed species on nickel catalysts encapsulated within mesoporous alumina. The temperature required for its complete desorption was 156 °C, while the introduction of Ag weakened the adsorption strength resulting in full furfuryl alcohol desorption already at 115 °C. The presence of weakly adsorbed anisole, along with coordinated species on Lewis sites on alumina support leading to the formation of phenate after heating to 150–200 °C was deduced by in-situ FTIR studies in [20,75]. The chemisorption of anisole through an interaction between the oxygen atom of anisole and catalyst surface was reported on HBEA above 100 °C, while no chemisorption was observed at room temperature [76]. It was suggested that the PhO−CH3 bond was cleaved, resulting in the formation of a surface methyl group resulting in the formation of phenate species containing an oxygen atom that is coordinated to a Lewis acid site. A similar situation was also confirmed for adsorption of guaiacol on alumina, where two types of adsorbed species were observed: the first one with weak H-bonding and the second one that was transformed upon heating into doubly anchored phenate species between guaiacol and alumina [20]. The authors proposed a model [20] in which the formation of a donor-acceptor complex with a Lewis acid site was followed by the transfer of a proton or methyl group to a Lewis basic site. It was observed that a decrease in alumina basicity led to the suppression of dissociative adsorption at room temperature, showing the importance of stabilization by proton transfer to the basic site. Also on HBEA it was speculated that two surface species were present [76]. The first species contained a methoxy group, and the oxygen atom of the dissociated phenol group was coordinated to a Lewis acid site, while the oxygen atom of the methoxy group was engaged in a Lewis acid/ base interaction, forming a methoxy phenate species. The second type of species involved the decomposition of the methoxy group, and both of the oxygen atoms appeared to be coordinated to one or more Lewis acid sites, forming a bidentate catecholate. Besides adsorption on alumina sites, the adsorption can also occur on metal clusters or the metal-support interface [77,78]. Kumar [79] suggested that anisole can also bind to metal clusters via its aromatic ring. Hu [75] confirmed by XPS under anisole pressure that the observed phenoxy species were formed at reduced metal sites. DFT calculations on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts showed that oxygen of furfuryl alcohol bound to Al sites adjacent to Cu cluster, where their carbon atoms also interacted with Cu cluster [67]. Therefore, additional adsorption mode on Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalysts can also be expected in comparison to pure alumina [75], especially if bigger metal clusters are formed [80]. Moreover, the acidity of the support may strongly influence how organics adsorb on the metal particles, mostly leading to preferential adsorption of oxygen-containing groups on the support rather than on the metal surface as acidic supports often enhance the adsorption of oxygenated groups (e.g., hydroxyl and methoxy) due to their affinity for oxygen atoms. The studies confirmed that chemisorption is important in organics adsorption on alumina-based catalysts. Since the formation of phenate species is related to the amount of Lewis acid sites on the oxide supports [20], the concentration of Lewis acid sites should also be a key factor in the formation of strongly adsorbed carbonaceous fragments that can cause catalyst poisoning/coking [80]. On the other hand, not only alumina acid sites are responsible for coke formation and different types of carbonaceous species that are formed on different catalyst sites can have different impacts. The TPO profiles of spent samples, i.e. after organics TPD (Fig. 19 , Table S9) confirmed the hypothesis that chemisorption of anisole, guaiacol and furfuryl alcohol, even at 36 °C, leads to species strongly bounded to the surface and these species results in the formation of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface during heating (TPD step). The oxidation resulted in the evolution of CO and CO2. The formation of CO and/or CO2 during TPO was dependent on the catalyst composition. CO formation was observed exclusively on bare alumina, with very low CO concentrations detected in the presence of either Cu or Ni. The highest amount of carbonaceous deposits was observed on bare alumina (Table S9). The total amount of carbonaceous residues correlated with the sample’s acidity (Table S4, Table S9). Since the formation of CO remained nearly constant for all samples it suggests the existence of two distinct sites on alumina capable of forming carbonaceous residuals. One of these sites, responsible for CO formation, is absent in metal-loaded samples, likely because it became covered by metal deposition. The amount of carbon deposits also depended on the organic molecule adsorbed. While adsorption and desorption of guaiacol resulted in the highest amount of carbonaceous deposits, the adsorption and desorption of anisole produced only a minimal amount of these, indicating that physisorption and weak chemisorption dominated anisole adsorption at 36 °C. These findings aligned with the anisole TPD results, where no dehydrogenation was observed and only CO2 evolution was detected. Differences in the positions of TPO peak maxima (Fig. 19) indicated variations in the type of deposited coke. The presence of Cu appeared to favour the formation of less refractory coke deposits as the TPO peak maximum was at lower temperature for guaiacol and furfuryl alcohol than in case of Ni10 and alumina support. Structural differences in coke deposits are typically associated with their oxidation reactivity. “Soft coke”, i.e. less refractory coke, characterized by less ordered and strongly adsorbed carbonaceous decomposition products, is oxidized at lower temperatures (200–320 °C), while “hard coke” species, with a low hydrogen-to-carbon ratio, can be oxidized only at higher temperatures up to 600 °C [76,81]. Low-temperature peaks are typically associated with coke formed on or near metal species, which catalyse its rapid combustion [82]. High-temperature peaks, however, correspond to coke located farther from the metal [82]. In our study, the carbonaceous deposits on Al2O3 support were oxidized only above 400 °C, while the carbonaceous deposits on metal-loaded samples were oxidized at 300 – 350 °C. Regardless of the adsorbed organics, two types of coke appeared to be present. This differentiation was most pronounced for Ni10, where distinct peak splitting was observed. These results indicate that different sites can contribute to varying types of carbonaceous deposits - one type forms directly on Al2O3, while another develops on metal-alumina interface. Since anisole produced almost no deposits, it supports hypothesis [83] that oxygenates containing more than one oxygen are significantly more prone to coke formation due to their readily self-polymerizing propensity. The conclusion that no carbon deposits were formed after anisole adsorption and subsequent heating was also corroborated by interesting features noticed during the activation period before TPO measurements. During sample heating up to 300 °C (not shown), CO2 evolution was observed for samples after adsorption - desorption test only with furfuryl alcohol and guaiacol. Since the samples were cooled after TPD in inert gas, the CO2 had to be adsorbed at ambient temperature from air during sample manipulation and storage. This means that carbon residues on the catalyst surface can adsorb CO₂ from the air at ambient temperature, although the extent and nature of this adsorption will depend on the characteristics of the carbon residue and the conditions. If the carbon residues are porous they have a high surface area and can adsorb gases like CO₂ effectively. Shown results indicate that organics adsorption is a very complex process depending on the type of catalyst, as well as the reactant and its concentration. Organics adsorb simultaneously in different modes: (i) weakly adsorbed species, that can be desorbed at ambient conditions, (ii) species adsorbed with medium strength that can be desorbed in original form by inert flow and heating (iii) strongly chemisorbed species that decompose during heating, while leaving behind carbonaceous residues and releasing gaseous products. In the chemisorption mode, furfuryl alcohol mainly undergoes unselective decomposition to CO, CO2 and H2 and to a lower extent dehydrogenation and decarbonylation producing methyl furan, furfural and furan; the process is more pronounced for Ni-loaded samples. Strongly adsorbed guaiacol is also subjected to unselective decomposition and similarly to furfuryl alcohol it is more dominant on Ni10. Moreover, demethylation/methylation reaction yielding dimethoxybenzene also proceed, however to a lower extent. Contrary to that, anisole adsorption is much weaker, without the formation of additional products during heating and carbonaceous deposits. Since decomposition products (H2, CO, CO2) are not virtually observed over alumina but alumina contains the highest amount of carbonaceous deposits, the residual surface carbonaceous species have to be in the form with lower graphitization degree compared to residues formed on metal loaded samples. In all cases, the balance of metallic sites and acid centres contributes to the selectivity/reactivity of the catalysts as well as total adsorption capacity. 4 Conclusions The study provides a comprehensive characterization of Ni and Cu catalysts supported on alumina. Metal deposition caused a surface area decrease, more dominant with loading above 10 wt. %. At low loadings, isolated Cu sites interacting with support were formed in Cu/Al2O3. With increasing Cu loading CuO clusters and later bulk CuO were formed. A reduction temperature of 250 °C was not sufficient for the reduction of highly isolated Cu2+ ions interacting with support corresponding to loadings below 2 wt. % and for highly dispersed species even temperature 480 °C is necessary for their complete reduction. Ni/Al2O3 catalysts contained various type of Ni species - NiO, NiO-like and spinel- like as well as NiAl2O4 spinel. Regarding surface arrangement spinel is formed in the vicinity of the support phase and it is covered by other phases. Therefore, the surface is predominantly covered by NiO and NiO-like species. Up to 480 °C only NiO type of species can be reduced. In bimetallic samples, Cu addition influences reducibility of Ni species depending on the total metal loading. For low Cu loadings, there is a positive effect on the reducibility, while for higher Cu loadings, nickel is probably covered by copper. Therefore, its reduction is hindered. Surface composition determined by XPS shows that NiO was formed on the surface only on bimetallic samples with total metal loading higher than 10 wt. %, thus on samples with lowered surface area, emphasizing the importance of Cu to Ni addition. Acidity is governed by alumina surface and decreases with increasing metal loading; acid strength distribution is very similar for all catalysts and the alumina support - all types of sites are. However, nickel-containing catalysts possess additional metal acid sites capable of NH3 decomposition. Accessible Ni surface area is strongly dependent on the reduction temperature as well as phase and chemical composition. In bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts, the Cu presence is beneficial for hydrogenation reactions if the reduction is performed around 500 °C either due to increased nickel availability or by boosting hydrogen spillover as was observed from H2-TPD. Cu surface area increases with Cu loading (up to 10 wt. %), while its dispersion decreases. However, N2O chemisorption method is not accurate for bimetallic samples, when Cu species are simultaneously reduced with those of Ni. Nonetheless For monometallic Cu catalysts the method can be used, but reduction temperature must be set individually from sample to sample especially for samples with loading below 3 wt. % Cu supported on high surface areas supports. The dependencies highlight the significant importance and impact of reduction treatment conditions on the derived conclusions. H2-TPD results show that for samples that are not fully reduced (reduction up to 600 °C) the peaks observed below the temperature used for hydrogen cleaning belong to H2 desorbed from metal particles and spillover hydrogen. The peaks above the temperature used for hydrogen cleaning belong to residual hydrogen reduction step diffused to subsurface layers. For samples that are fully reduced (reduction at 800 °C), high-temperature peaks belong to hydrogen adsorbed on reduced spinels, while spillover caused by simultaneous existence of reduced/unreduced nickel species presence which are capable of activating hydrogen is not observed. Copper presence causes the increase in hydrogen adsorption either by increased nickel availability or by spillover caused by the migration of hydrogen from Ni to Cu species in the newly formed alloy phase. H2-TPD technique can bring important observations relevant to HDO catalytic reactions. Organics adsorption is a complex process influenced by catalyst type, used organic compound, and concentration. Acid sites on alumina are crucial for the adsorption of anisole, guaiacol, and furfuryl alcohol. Introduced Ni and Cu reduce acidity, which decreases the amount of adsorbed organics. For furfuryl alcohol, Cu offers additional adsorption sites that do not attract anisole and guaiacol. Adsorption capacity also depends on the organic concentration. The subsequent desorption depends on adsorbed compound and metal loading. Adsorbed Furfuryl alcohol and guaiacol decompose to a large extent unselectively during heating, while anisole has distinct adsorption behaviours. Ni and Cu support coke deposits forming species with a high carbon ratio compared to alumina. The highest number of carbonaceous deposits was on alumina after the guaiacol adsorption while anisole desorbs with almost no residues. In all cases, the balance of metallic sites and acid centres contributes to the selectivity/reactivity of the catalysts as well as total adsorption capacity. The findings indicate that further adsorption/desorption studies under catalytic reaction conditions, especially at a specific elevated temperature, are necessary to fully understand catalyst behaviour at specific reaction conditions. However, the extent of reduction and processes connected with partial catalyst reduction will play an important role in the metal catalysis. Therefore, to completely understand the relationship between catalytic performance and physico-chemical properties, the material characterizations have to be done at conditions very close to those maintained during the catalytic reaction with special emphasis on reduction conditions. coredata.dc:description: Paper provides a comprehensive study of Ni-Cu catalysts on alumina, focusing on the effects of metal loading, reduction temperatures, and bimetallic interactions on catalyst properties and adsorption behaviour of model organic molecules. Introduction of metal reduces catalyst surface area. Low Cu loadings promote formation of isolated Cu sites, higher result in large CuO clusters. Ni catalysts have composition consisting of a mixture of NiO, NiO-like, and spinel species and the surface is primarily covered by NiO. Bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts reveal Cu enhanced hydrogenation ability and reducibility. Acidity, primarily originating from alumina, decreases with increasing metal loading, however increasing nickel loading induces new type of sites capable of decomposing NH₃. Reduced acidity limits anisole and guaiacol adsorption, while the presence of Cu provides additional adsorption sites for furfuryl alcohol. Organics exhibit distinct adsorption modes with following desorption and/or decomposition during thermal heating influenced by metal loading, catalyst composition and organics type. Incorporating Ni and Cu affects coke deposits: the most deposits are formed on alumina after guaiacol adsorption, while anisole leaves no carbonaceous residues. The study highlights the importance of reduction conditions on catalytic performance, advocating further research on adsorption under reaction-like conditions to understand the catalysts’ behaviour in practical applications.
